criticalSuccess: Your fingers move with the practiced precision of a master thief. You time your approach perfectly, waiting for the exact moment of distraction. Your hand moves smoothly and naturally, fingers finding the item with unerring accuracy. The transfer is seamless - one moment it's theirs, the next it's yours. They notice nothing. Your technique is so polished they won't realize it's missing until much later, if ever. Perfect theft!

Your sleight of hand is impeccable. You approach with perfect casualness, your hand moving with practiced ease. The item transfers from their possession to yours in one fluid motion they never even notice. Textbook perfect theft!

criticalFailure: Your theft attempt goes catastrophically wrong. Maybe your timing is terrible, maybe your fingers fumble, or maybe you're just unlucky. Whatever the cause, they catch you red-handed. Your hand is literally on or in their belongings when they notice. There's no talking your way out of this - you've been caught stealing!

Disaster strikes your pickpocket attempt. Your approach is too obvious, your hand movements too noticeable, or your timing completely wrong. They catch you in the act of stealing, your hand on their property. You're caught, and they know exactly what you were trying to do!

Your theft fails in the most blatant way possible. They notice your hand moving toward their belongings and catch your wrist before you can even touch the item. You're caught attempting theft, and there's no denying it!

criticalSuccess: You are an artist, and theft is your canvas. You read their body language, understanding their attention and awareness. You see the perfect moment - that instant of distraction, that gap in focus. Your hand moves with practiced fluidity, fingers trained by hundreds of successful thefts. The movement is natural, unremarkable, completely innocent to any observer. Your fingers find the item with tactile precision, lifting it with the gentlest touch. The transfer is seamless, the weight redistributed so gradually they don't even feel the difference. One moment the item is theirs, the next it's yours, and the transition is so smooth it might as well be magic. They'll never know it's gone until they look for it, and by then you'll be long gone. This is theft elevated to an art form!

Like a magician performing sleight of hand, you manipulate perception and reality. Your approach is perfectly timed, your demeanor completely innocent. Your hand moves with such natural fluidity that any observer would swear you were doing nothing suspicious. Your fingers are quick and precise, trained to perfection. The item leaves their possession so smoothly it might as well have teleported. There's no fumbling, no hesitation, no tell-tale signs. Just smooth, professional, perfect theft. The item is now yours, and they're completely clueless. You've stolen something right from under their nose, and they'll never know!
success: You execute a functional theft. Your technique is competent, your timing adequate. You take the item without immediate detection. It's not the smoothest pickpocket ever performed, but it works. You have what you wanted.
You successfully steal the item using solid technique and decent timing. Your sleight of hand is good enough to avoid detection. The theft succeeds, though it's not perfect art.
failure: You attempt the theft, but it fails. Maybe they're more alert than you anticipated, maybe your technique isn't quite smooth enough, or maybe you're just unlucky. Whatever the reason, they notice your attempt before you can complete it. Your hand reaching for their belongings is spotted, and the theft is foiled.

Your pickpocket attempt is detected. You thought you had the perfect moment, the right approach, but something goes wrong. They notice your hand, your movement, your intent. You're caught attempting to steal, and you don't get the item.
criticalFailure: Everything goes wrong in the worst possible way. Maybe you misjudge their awareness, maybe your hand fumbles at the critical moment, maybe simple bad luck intervenes. But the result is undeniable and embarrassing. They catch you red-handed in the act of theft. Your hand is on their belongings, or in their pocket, or holding their item when they notice. There's no plausible deniability, no innocent explanation. You've been caught stealing, caught so obviously that there's no talking your way out of it. It's a complete and total failure!

Your theft attempt becomes a disaster. You thought you were being smooth and subtle, but apparently you were neither. They notice immediately - catching your hand in the act, seeing the theft in progress. You're caught so blatantly that everyone nearby knows exactly what you were trying to do. It's not just a failed theft, it's a spectacular fumble that's caught you red-handed!
